subject: Re: [junit] Re: Asserts after every test
msgSnippet: In the latest JUnit 4.7 snapshot, you ll be able to use the @Interceptor notation to do the following: public static class ErrorLogVerifier() { private
messageBody:
In the latest JUnit 4.7 snapshot, you'll be able to use the
@Interceptor notation to do the following:

public static class ErrorLogVerifier() {
private ErrorLog errorLog = new ErrorLog();

@Interceptor
public Verifier verifier = new Verifier() {
@Override public void verify() {
// only run if the test was successful
assertTrue(errorLog.isEmpty());
}
}

@Test public void testThatMightWriteErrorLog() {
// ...
}
}

The 4.7 release is pretty stable at this point, except for the typing
on assertThat, so I feel fairly comfortable recommending its use.

David Saff

> David,

>  Thank you very much for the reply.  I am using JUnit 4 with the @After annotation.  I can't quite tell what the issue is, but it seems that maybe IDEA and/or TeamCity is not always reporting all of the errors when there is a multiple exception scenario.  I was doing some testing after my original post, and the behavior was inconsistent.
>
>  Regardless, am I missing anything here with respect to a way to assert state after any test in a class is run?  I've seen many posts where people preach about not asserting in tearDown/@After, but no one seems to offer any alternatives.  Is this simply something not currently available in JUnit?  If not, I wonder if this is something the current maintainers would consider useful.  Maybe an @AfterAssert or something that notes a method that should be run after the test only if the test did not have any assertion failures itself.
>
> Regards,
> Paul
